pull.title: Update to use OpenSSL 1.0.1c
pull.body:
Use OpenSSL 1.0.1c
Bump deps to 0.0.5
Small docs corrections

events.message:
Update Bitcoin to use OpenSSL 1.0.1c

Bump deps tp 0.0.5
Small docs corrections

events.body: Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/0eaaa83ba521af8453c11ad688bdbb6bd4e33870 for binaries and test log.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ Licenses of statically linked libraries:
 
 Versions used in this release:
  GCC           4.3.3
- OpenSSL       0.9.8g
+ OpenSSL       1.0.1c
comments.body: What I find strange is, that my tests in a Ubuntu VM with Gitian, bitcoin-qt showed used OpenSSL version as 0.9.8, is that true, that we use such an "old" version with the official Linux bins?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ Licenses of statically linked libraries:
 
 Versions used in this release:
  GCC           4.3.3
- OpenSSL       0.9.8g
+ OpenSSL       1.0.1c
comments.body: In any proper OS install, the OS is responsible for the version of OpenSSL used.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ Licenses of statically linked libraries:
 
 Versions used in this release:
  GCC           4.3.3
- OpenSSL       0.9.8g
+ OpenSSL       1.0.1c
comments.body: Im a Linux noob, sorry ... but your statement is false for the Windows binary, as we statically link to OpenSSL there ;).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ Licenses of statically linked libraries:
 
 Versions used in this release:

comments.body: Yes, I don't consider Windows to be a proper OS ;)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@ Licenses of statically linked libraries:

comments.body: Fine, same is true for me thinking about Linux ;). End of OT then ^^.
